an6.54:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati gijjhakūṭe pabbate.
an6.54:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.

an6.54:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā dhammiko jātibhūmiyaṃ āvāsiko hoti sabbaso jātibhūmiyaṃ sattasu āvāsesu.
an6.54:1.2.eng: Now at that time Venerable Dhammika was a resident in all seven monasteries of his native land.

an6.54:1.3.pli: Tatra sudaṃ āyasmā dhammiko āgantuke bhikkhū akkosati paribhāsati vihiṃsati vitudati roseti vācāya.
an6.54:1.3.eng: There he abused visiting mendicants; he insulted, harmed, attacked, and harassed them.

an6.54:1.4.pli: Te ca āgantukā bhikkhū āyasmatā dhammikena akkosiyamānā paribhāsiyamānā vihesiyamānā vitudiyamānā rosiyamānā vācāya pakkamanti, na saṇṭhanti, riñcanti āvāsaṃ.
an6.54:1.4.eng: The visiting mendicants who were treated in this way did not stay. They left, abandoning the monastery.

an6.54:2.1.eng: Then the local lay followers thought to themselves,

an6.54:2.2.eng: “We have supplied the mendicant Saṅgha with robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.

an6.54:2.3.pli: Atha ca pana āgantukā bhikkhū pakkamanti, na saṇṭhanti, riñcanti āvāsaṃ.
an6.54:2.3.eng: But the visiting mendicants don’t stay. They leave, abandoning the monastery.

an6.54:2.4.pli: Ko nu kho hetu ko paccayo yena āgantukā bhikkhū pakkamanti, na saṇṭhanti, riñcanti āvāsan”ti?
an6.54:2.4.eng: What is the cause, what is the reason for this?”

an6.54:2.5.eng: Then the local lay followers thought to themselves,

an6.54:2.6.pli: “ayaṃ kho āyasmā dhammiko āgantuke bhikkhū akkosati paribhāsati vihiṃsati vitudati roseti vācāya.
an6.54:2.6.eng: “This Venerable Dhammika abuses visiting mendicants; he insults, harms, attacks, and harasses them.

an6.54:2.7.pli: Te ca āgantukā bhikkhū āyasmatā dhammikena akkosiyamānā paribhāsiyamānā vihesiyamānā vitudiyamānā rosiyamānā vācāya pakkamanti, na saṇṭhanti, riñcanti āvāsaṃ.
an6.54:2.7.eng: The visiting mendicants who were treated in this way do not stay. They leave, abandoning the monastery.

an6.54:2.8.eng: Why don’t we banish Venerable Dhammika?”

an6.54:3.1.pli: Atha kho jātibhūmakā upāsakā yena āyasmā dhammiko tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ dhammikaṃ etadavocuṃ:
an6.54:3.1.eng: Then the local lay followers went up to Venerable Dhammika and said to him,

an6.54:3.4.pli: Atha kho āyasmā dhammiko tamhā āvāsā aññaṃ āvāsaṃ agamāsi.
an6.54:3.4.eng: Then Venerable Dhammika left and went to another monastery.

an6.54:3.5.pli: Tatrapi sudaṃ āyasmā dhammiko āgantuke bhikkhū akkosati paribhāsati vihiṃsati vitudati roseti vācāya.
an6.54:3.5.eng: There he abused visiting mendicants; he insulted, harmed, attacked, and harassed them.

an6.54:3.6.pli: Te ca āgantukā bhikkhū āyasmatā dhammikena akkosiyamānā paribhāsiyamānā vihesiyamānā vitudiyamānā rosiyamānā vācāya pakkamanti, na saṇṭhanti, riñcanti āvāsaṃ.
an6.54:3.6.eng: The visiting mendicants who were treated in this way did not stay. They left, abandoning the monastery.

an6.54:4.1.eng: Then the local lay followers thought to themselves: …

an6.54:4.3.pli: Atha ca pana āgantukā bhikkhū pakkamanti, na saṇṭhanti, riñcanti āvāsaṃ.

an6.54:4.4.pli: Ko nu kho hetu ko paccayo yena āgantukā bhikkhū pakkamanti, na saṇṭhanti, riñcanti āvāsan”ti?

an6.54:4.6.pli: “ayaṃ kho āyasmā dhammiko āgantuke bhikkhū akkosati paribhāsati vihiṃsati vitudati roseti vācāya.

an6.54:4.7.pli: Te ca āgantukā bhikkhū āyasmatā dhammikena akkosiyamānā paribhāsiyamānā vihesiyamānā vitudiyamānā rosiyamānā vācāya pakkamanti, na saṇṭhanti, riñcanti āvāsaṃ.

an6.54:5.1.pli: Atha kho jātibhūmakā upāsakā yenāyasmā dhammiko tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ dhammikaṃ etadavocuṃ:

an6.54:5.4.pli: Atha kho āyasmā dhammiko tamhāpi āvāsā aññaṃ āvāsaṃ agamāsi.
an6.54:5.4.eng: Then Venerable Dhammika left and went to another monastery.

an6.54:5.5.pli: Tatrapi sudaṃ āyasmā dhammiko āgantuke bhikkhū akkosati paribhāsati vihiṃsati vitudati roseti vācāya.
an6.54:5.5.eng: There he abused visiting mendicants; he insulted, harmed, attacked, and harassed them.

an6.54:5.6.pli: Te ca āgantukā bhikkhū āyasmatā dhammikena akkosiyamānā paribhāsiyamānā vihesiyamānā vitudiyamānā rosiyamānā vācāya pakkamanti, na saṇṭhanti, riñcanti āvāsaṃ.
an6.54:5.6.eng: The visiting mendicants who were treated in this way did not stay. They left, abandoning the monastery.

an6.54:6.1.eng: Then the local lay followers thought to themselves,

an6.54:6.3.pli: Atha ca pana āgantukā bhikkhū pakkamanti, na saṇṭhanti, riñcanti āvāsaṃ.

an6.54:6.4.pli: Ko nu kho hetu ko paccayo yena āgantukā bhikkhū pakkamanti, na saṇṭhanti, riñcanti āvāsan”ti?

an6.54:6.5.pli: Atha kho jātibhūmakānaṃ upāsakānaṃ etadahosi: “ayaṃ kho āyasmā dhammiko āgantuke bhikkhū akkosati …pe….

an6.54:6.6.pli: Yannūna mayaṃ āyasmantaṃ dhammikaṃ pabbājeyyāma sabbaso jātibhūmiyaṃ sattahi āvāsehī”ti.
an6.54:6.6.eng: “Why don’t we banish Venerable Dhammika from all seven monasteries in our native land?”

an6.54:6.7.pli: Atha kho jātibhūmakā upāsakā yenāyasmā dhammiko tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ dhammikaṃ etadavocuṃ:
an6.54:6.7.eng: Then the local lay followers went up to Venerable Dhammika and said to him,

an6.54:6.8.pli: “pakkamatu, bhante, āyasmā dhammiko sabbaso jātibhūmiyaṃ sattahi āvāsehī”ti.
an6.54:6.8.eng: “Sir, please leave all seven monasteries in our native land.”

an6.54:6.10.pli: “pabbājito khomhi jātibhūmakehi upāsakehi sabbaso jātibhūmiyaṃ sattahi āvāsehi.
an6.54:6.10.eng: “I’ve been banished by the local lay followers from all seven monasteries in my native land.

an6.54:6.11.eng: Where am I to go now?”

an6.54:6.13.eng: “Why don’t I go to see the Buddha?”

an6.54:7.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā dhammiko pattacīvaramādāya yena rājagahaṃ tena pakkāmi.
an6.54:7.1.eng: Then Venerable Dhammika took his bowl and robe and set out for Rājagaha.

an6.54:7.2.pli: Anupubbena yena rājagahaṃ gijjhakūṭo pabbato yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ dhammikaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
an6.54:7.2.eng: Eventually he came to Rājagaha and the Vulture’s Peak. He went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him,

an6.54:7.3.pli: “handa kuto nu tvaṃ, brāhmaṇa dhammika, āgacchasī”ti?
an6.54:7.3.eng: “So, Brahmin Dhammika, where have you come from?”

an6.54:7.4.pli: “Pabbājito ahaṃ, bhante, jātibhūmakehi upāsakehi sabbaso jātibhūmiyaṃ sattahi āvāsehī”ti.
an6.54:7.4.eng: “Sir, I’ve been banished by the local lay followers from all seven monasteries in my native land.”

an6.54:7.5.pli: “Alaṃ, brāhmaṇa dhammika, kiṃ te iminā, yaṃ taṃ tato tato pabbājenti, so tvaṃ tato tato pabbājito mameva santike āgacchasi.
an6.54:7.5.eng: “Enough, Brahmin Dhammika, what’s that to you? Now that you’ve been banished from all of those places, you have come to me.

an6.54:8.1.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ, brāhmaṇa dhammika, sāmuddikā vāṇijā tīradassiṃ sakuṇaṃ gahetvā nāvāya samuddaṃ ajjhogāhanti.
an6.54:8.1.eng: Once upon a time, some sea-merchants set sail for the ocean deeps, taking with them a land-spotting bird.

an6.54:8.2.pli: Te atīradakkhiṇiyā nāvāya tīradassiṃ sakuṇaṃ muñcanti.
an6.54:8.2.eng: When their ship was out of sight of land, they released the bird.

an6.54:8.3.pli: So gacchateva puratthimaṃ disaṃ, gacchati pacchimaṃ disaṃ, gacchati uttaraṃ disaṃ, gacchati dakkhiṇaṃ disaṃ, gacchati uddhaṃ, gacchati anudisaṃ.
an6.54:8.3.eng: It flew right away to the east, the west, the north, the south, upwards, and in-between.

an6.54:8.4.pli: Sace so samantā tīraṃ passati, tathāgatakova hoti.
an6.54:8.4.eng: If it saw land on any side, it went there and stayed.

an6.54:8.5.pli: Sace pana so samantā tīraṃ na passati tameva nāvaṃ paccāgacchati.
an6.54:8.5.eng: But if it saw no land on any side it returned to the ship.

an6.54:8.6.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa dhammika, yaṃ taṃ tato tato pabbājenti so tvaṃ tato tato pabbājito mameva santike āgacchasi.
an6.54:8.6.eng: In the same way, now that you’ve been banished from all of those places, you have come to me.

an6.54:9.1.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ, brāhmaṇa dhammika, rañño korabyassa suppatiṭṭho nāma nigrodharājā ahosi pañcasākho sītacchāyo manoramo.
an6.54:9.1.eng: Once upon a time, King Koravya had a royal banyan tree with five trunks called ‘Well Planted’. It was shady and lovely.

an6.54:9.2.pli: Suppatiṭṭhassa kho pana, brāhmaṇa dhammika, nigrodharājassa dvādasayojanāni abhiniveso ahosi, pañca yojanāni mūlasantānakānaṃ.
an6.54:9.2.eng: Its canopy spread over twelve leagues, while the network of roots spread for five leagues.

an6.54:9.3.pli: Suppatiṭṭhassa kho pana, brāhmaṇa dhammika, nigrodharājassa tāva mahantāni phalāni ahesuṃ;
an6.54:9.3.eng: Its fruits were as large as

an6.54:9.5.eng: And they were as sweet as

an6.54:9.7.pli: Suppatiṭṭhassa kho pana, brāhmaṇa dhammika, nigrodharājassa ekaṃ khandhaṃ rājā paribhuñjati saddhiṃ itthāgārena, ekaṃ khandhaṃ balakāyo paribhuñjati, ekaṃ khandhaṃ negamajānapadā paribhuñjanti, ekaṃ khandhaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇā paribhuñjanti, ekaṃ khandhaṃ migā paribhuñjanti.
an6.54:9.7.eng: The king and harem made use of one trunk, the troops another, the people of town and country another, ascetics and brahmins another, and beasts and birds another.

an6.54:9.8.pli: Suppatiṭṭhassa kho pana, brāhmaṇa dhammika, nigrodharājassa na koci phalāni rakkhati, na ca sudaṃ aññamaññassa phalāni hiṃsanti.
an6.54:9.8.eng: No-one guarded the fruit, yet no-one damaged another’s fruits.

an6.54:10.1.pli: Atha kho, brāhmaṇa dhammika, aññataro puriso suppatiṭṭhassa nigrodharājassa yāvadatthaṃ phalāni bhakkhitvā sākhaṃ bhañjitvā pakkāmi.
an6.54:10.1.eng: Then a certain person ate as much as he liked of the fruit, then broke off a branch and left.

an6.54:10.2.pli: Atha kho, brāhmaṇa dhammika, suppatiṭṭhe nigrodharāje adhivatthāya devatāya etadahosi:
an6.54:10.2.eng: Then the deity haunting the royal banyan tree thought,

an6.54:10.4.pli: Yāva pāpo manusso, yatra hi nāma suppatiṭṭhassa nigrodharājassa yāvadatthaṃ phalāni bhakkhitvā sākhaṃ bhañjitvā pakkamissati, yannūna suppatiṭṭho nigrodharājā āyatiṃ phalaṃ na dadeyyā’ti.
an6.54:10.4.eng: How wicked this person is, to eat as much as they like, then break off a branch and leave! Why don’t I make sure that the royal banyan tree gives no fruit in future?’

an6.54:10.5.pli: Atha kho, brāhmaṇa dhammika, suppatiṭṭho nigrodharājā āyatiṃ phalaṃ na adāsi.
an6.54:10.5.eng: Then the royal banyan tree gave no more fruit.

an6.54:11.1.pli: Atha kho, brāhmaṇa dhammika, rājā korabyo yena sakko devānamindo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā sakkaṃ devānamindaṃ etadavoca:
an6.54:11.1.eng: Then King Koravya went up to Sakka, lord of gods, and said to him,

an6.54:11.2.pli: ‘yagghe, mārisa, jāneyyāsi suppatiṭṭho nigrodharājā phalaṃ na detī’ti.
an6.54:11.2.eng: ‘Please good fellow, you should know that the royal banyan tree called Well Planted gives no fruit.’

an6.54:11.3.pli: Atha kho, brāhmaṇa dhammika, sakko devānamindo tathārūpaṃ iddhābhisaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkhāsi, yathā bhusā vātavuṭṭhi āgantvā suppatiṭṭhaṃ nigrodharājaṃ pavattesi ummūlamakāsi.
an6.54:11.3.eng: Then Sakka used his psychic powers to will that a violent storm come. And it felled and uprooted the royal banyan tree.

an6.54:11.4.pli: Atha kho, brāhmaṇa dhammika, suppatiṭṭhe nigrodharāje adhivatthā devatā dukkhī dummanā assumukhī rudamānā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi.
an6.54:11.4.eng: Then the deity haunting the tree stood to one side, miserable and sad, weeping, with a tearful face.

an6.54:12.1.pli: Atha kho, brāhmaṇa dhammika, sakko devānamindo yena suppatiṭṭhe nigrodharāje adhivatthā devatā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā suppatiṭṭhe nigrodharāje adhivatthaṃ devataṃ etadavoca:
an6.54:12.1.eng: Then Sakka went up to that deity, and said,

an6.54:12.2.pli: ‘kiṃ nu tvaṃ, devate, dukkhī dummanā assumukhī rudamānā ekamantaṃ ṭhitā’ti?
an6.54:12.2.eng: ‘Why, god, are you standing to one side, miserable and sad, weeping, with a tearful face?’

an6.54:12.3.pli: ‘Tathā hi pana me, mārisa, bhusā vātavuṭṭhi āgantvā bhavanaṃ pavattesi ummūlamakāsī’ti.
an6.54:12.3.eng: ‘Because, my good fellow, a violent storm came and felled and uprooted my home.’

an6.54:12.4.pli: ‘Api nu tvaṃ, devate, rukkhadhamme ṭhitāya bhusā vātavuṭṭhi āgantvā bhavanaṃ pavattesi ummūlamakāsī’ti?
an6.54:12.4.eng: ‘Well, did you stand by your tree’s duty when the storm came?’

an6.54:12.5.pli: ‘Kathaṃ pana, mārisa, rukkho rukkhadhamme ṭhito hotī’ti?
an6.54:12.5.eng: ‘But my good fellow, how does a tree stand by its duty?’

an6.54:12.6.pli: ‘Idha, devate, rukkhassa mūlaṃ mūlatthikā haranti, tacaṃ tacatthikā haranti, pattaṃ pattatthikā haranti, pupphaṃ pupphatthikā haranti, phalaṃ phalatthikā haranti.
an6.54:12.6.eng: ‘It’s when those who need the tree’s roots, bark, leaves, flowers, or fruit take what they need.

an6.54:12.7.pli: Na ca tena devatāya anattamanatā vā anabhinandi vā karaṇīyā.
an6.54:12.7.eng: Yet the deity is not displeased or upset because of this.

an6.54:12.8.pli: Evaṃ kho, devate, rukkho rukkhadhamme ṭhito hotī’ti.
an6.54:12.8.eng: This is how a tree stands by its duty.’

an6.54:12.9.pli: ‘Aṭṭhitāyeva kho me, mārisa, rukkhadhamme bhusā vātavuṭṭhi āgantvā bhavanaṃ pavattesi ummūlamakāsī’ti.
an6.54:12.9.eng: ‘I was not standing by a tree’s duty when the storm came and felled and uprooted my home.’

an6.54:12.10.pli: ‘Sace kho tvaṃ, devate, rukkhadhamme tiṭṭheyyāsi, siyā te bhavanaṃ yathāpure’ti.
an6.54:12.10.eng: ‘God, if you were to stand by a tree’s duty, your home may be as it was before.’

an6.54:12.11.pli: ‘Ṭhassāmahaṃ, mārisa, rukkhadhamme, hotu me bhavanaṃ yathāpure’ti.
an6.54:12.11.eng: ‘I will stand by a tree’s duty! May my home be as it was before!’

an6.54:13.1.pli: Atha kho, brāhmaṇa dhammika, sakko devānamindo tathārūpaṃ iddhābhisaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkhāsi, yathā bhusā vātavuṭṭhi āgantvā suppatiṭṭhaṃ nigrodharājaṃ ussāpesi, sacchavīni mūlāni ahesuṃ.
an6.54:13.1.eng: Then Sakka used his psychic power to will that a violent storm come. And it raised up that mighty banyan tree and the bark of the roots was healed.

an6.54:13.2.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa dhammika, api nu taṃ samaṇadhamme ṭhitaṃ jātibhūmakā upāsakā pabbājesuṃ sabbaso jātibhūmiyaṃ sattahi āvāsehī”ti?
an6.54:13.2.eng: In the same way, Brahmin Dhammika, were you standing by an ascetic’s duty when the local lay followers banished you from all seven of the monasteries in your native land?”

an6.54:13.3.pli: “Kathaṃ pana, bhante, samaṇo samaṇadhamme ṭhito hotī”ti?
an6.54:13.3.eng: “But sir, how do I stand by an ascetic’s duty?”

an6.54:13.4.pli: “Idha, brāhmaṇa dhammika, samaṇo akkosantaṃ na paccakkosati, rosantaṃ na paṭirosati, bhaṇḍantaṃ na paṭibhaṇḍati.
an6.54:13.4.eng: “When someone abuses, annoys, or argues with an ascetic, the ascetic doesn’t abuse, annoy, or argue back at them.

an6.54:13.5.pli: Evaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa dhammika, samaṇo samaṇadhamme ṭhito hotī”ti.
an6.54:13.5.eng: That’s how an ascetic stands by an ascetic’s duty.”

an6.54:13.6.pli: “Aṭṭhitaṃyeva maṃ, bhante, samaṇadhamme jātibhūmakā upāsakā pabbājesuṃ sabbaso jātibhūmiyaṃ sattahi āvāsehī”ti.
an6.54:13.6.eng: “I was not standing by an ascetic’s duty when the local lay followers banished me from all seven of the monasteries in my native land.”

an6.54:13.7.pli: “Bhūtapubbaṃ, brāhmaṇa dhammika, sunetto nāma satthā ahosi titthakaro kāmesu vītarāgo.
an6.54:13.7.eng: “Once upon a time, there was a teacher named Sunetta. He was a religious founder and was free of desire for sensual pleasures.

an6.54:13.8.pli: Sunettassa kho pana, brāhmaṇa dhammika, satthuno anekāni sāvakasatāni ahesuṃ.
an6.54:13.8.eng: He had many hundreds of disciples.

an6.54:13.9.pli: Sunetto satthā sāvakānaṃ brahmalokasahabyatāya dhammaṃ desesi.
an6.54:13.9.eng: He taught them the path to rebirth in the company of Divinity.

an6.54:13.10.pli: Ye kho pana, brāhmaṇa dhammika, sunettassa satthuno brahmalokasahabyatāya dhammaṃ desentassa cittāni na pasādesuṃ te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjiṃsu.
an6.54:13.10.eng: Those lacking confidence in Sunetta were—when their body broke up, after death—reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

an6.54:13.11.pli: Ye kho pana, brāhmaṇa dhammika, sunettassa satthuno brahmalokasahabyatāya dhammaṃ desentassa cittāni pasādesuṃ te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjiṃsu.
an6.54:13.11.eng: Those full of confidence in Sunetta were—when their body broke up, after death—reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

an6.54:14.1.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ, brāhmaṇa dhammika, mūgapakkho nāma satthā ahosi …pe…
an6.54:14.1.eng: Once upon a time there was a teacher named Mūgapakkha …

an6.54:18.1.pli: … Jotipālo nāma satthā ahosi titthakaro kāmesu vītarāgo.
an6.54:18.1.eng: Jotipāla. He was a religious founder and was free of desire for sensual pleasures.

an6.54:18.2.pli: Jotipālassa kho pana, brāhmaṇa dhammika, satthuno anekāni sāvakasatāni ahesuṃ.
an6.54:18.2.eng: He had many hundreds of disciples.

an6.54:18.3.pli: Jotipālo satthā sāvakānaṃ brahmalokasahabyatāya dhammaṃ desesi.
an6.54:18.3.eng: He taught them the way to rebirth in the company of Divinity.

an6.54:18.4.pli: Ye kho pana, brāhmaṇa dhammika, jotipālassa satthuno brahmalokasahabyatāya dhammaṃ desentassa cittāni na pasādesuṃ te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjiṃsu.
an6.54:18.4.eng: Those lacking confidence in Jotipāla were—when their body broke up, after death—reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

an6.54:18.5.pli: Ye kho pana, brāhmaṇa dhammika, jotipālassa satthuno brahmalokasahabyatāya dhammaṃ desentassa cittāni pasādesuṃ te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjiṃsu.
an6.54:18.5.eng: Those full of confidence in Jotipāla were—when their body broke up, after death—reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

an6.54:19.1.eng: What do you think, Brahmin Dhammika?

an6.54:19.2.pli: yo ime cha satthāre titthakare kāmesu vītarāge, anekasataparivāre sasāvakasaṅghe paduṭṭhacitto akkoseyya paribhāseyya, bahuṃ so apuññaṃ pasaveyyā”ti?
an6.54:19.2.eng: If someone with malicious intent were to abuse and insult these six teachers with their hundreds of followers, would they not brim with much wickedness?”

an6.54:19.4.pli: “Yo kho, brāhmaṇa dhammika, ime cha satthāre titthakare kāmesu vītarāge anekasataparivāre sasāvakasaṅghe paduṭṭhacitto akkoseyya paribhāseyya, bahuṃ so apuññaṃ pasaveyya.

an6.54:19.5.pli: Yo ekaṃ diṭṭhisampannaṃ puggalaṃ paduṭṭhacitto akkosati paribhāsati, ayaṃ tato bahutaraṃ apuññaṃ pasavati.
an6.54:19.5.eng: But someone who abuses and insults a single individual accomplished in view with malicious intent brims even more with wickedness.

an6.54:19.7.pli: Nāhaṃ, brāhmaṇa dhammika, ito bahiddhā evarūpiṃ khantiṃ vadāmi, yathāmaṃ sabrahmacārīsu.
an6.54:19.7.eng: Brahmin Dhammika, I say that any injury done by those outside of the Buddhist community does not compare with what is done to one’s own spiritual companions.

an6.54:19.8.eng: So you should train like this:

an6.54:19.9.eng: ‘We will have no malicious intent for those who we want to have as our spiritual companions.’

an6.54:19.10.eng: That is how you should train.

an6.54:22.2.eng: gone beyond the fetter of sensuality.

an6.54:22.4.eng: they were reborn in the realm of divinity.

an6.54:23.4.eng: gone beyond the fetter of sensuality.

an6.54:23.6.eng: they were reborn in the realm of divinity.

an6.54:24.4.eng: free of desire, immersed in samādhi;

an6.54:25.3.eng: a single individual accomplished in view,

an6.54:25.4.eng: a mendicant disciple of the Buddha;

an6.54:26.1.eng: You shouldn’t attack a holy person,

an6.54:26.2.eng: who has given up the grounds for views.

an6.54:26.4.eng: the seventh of the noble Saṅgha.

an6.54:27.1.eng: They’re not free of desire for sensual pleasures,

an6.54:27.2.eng: and their faculties are still immature:

an6.54:28.1.eng: If you attack such a mendicant,

an6.54:29.4.eng: An astute person is always uninjured.”
